item.headline: CIA4Uh_Week 1
item.content:
This week, you will:

  • formulate different types of questions to guide investigations into current national and global economic issues
  • select and organize relevant data, evidence, and information on current Canadian and international economic issues from a variety of primary and secondary sources
  • assess the credibility of sources, data, evidence, and information relevant to their investigations
  • interpret and analyze data, evidence, and information relevant to their investigations, using various tools, strategies, and approaches appropriate for economic inquiry
  • use the concepts of economic thinking
  • communicate their ideas, arguments, and conclusions using various formats and styles, as appropriate for the audience and purpose

TO DO:

Asking Economic Questions

Lesson Description:

In this lesson, you will learn about the role of economics in careers, the inquiry process, concepts of economic thinking, and how to cite your sources.

  • Complete Asking Economic Questions.
  • Answer all the activities for the lesson.

Thinking and Decision-Making

Lesson Description:

In this lesson, we will delve into the fundamental aspects of thinking and decision-making. Thinking encompasses mental processes like problem-solving and creativity, while decision-making involves selecting the best course of action from various options. Understanding these processes equips us with essential tools to make informed choices, tackle problems, and navigate life's challenges. We will explore thinking strategies, decision-making models, and the factors influencing our choices, enhancing our ability to lead intentional and fulfilling lives.

    • Complete the lesson: Thinking and Decision-Making.
    • Answer all the activities for the lesson.

Supply and Demand

Lesson Description:

In this lesson, we will uncover the fundamental economic principles of supply and demand. These concepts drive the dynamics of markets, from individual consumer choices to global economic policies.

  • Complete the lesson: Supply and Demand.
